title: 'The View' slams William H. Macy's support of Felicity Huffman ahead of sentencing
text:
Felicity Huffman's relationship with her two daughters "exploded" after the college admissions scandal went public.

That's what Huffman's husband, actor William H. Macy, revealed in a letter of support sent to Judge Indira Talwani ahead of Huffman’s sentencing this week.

"Rebuilding that relationship will be a long process,” he wrote of Huffman's bond with daughters Sophia, 19, and Georgia, 17, noting the family has been in therapy since the scandal broke. “But I also want you to know Felicity has raised two amazing young women.”

In his letter to the judge, obtained by USA TODAY, Macy attempted to explain why Huffman paid to have a proctor correct Sophia's SAT answers, inflating her test scores.

Macy said Huffman's own mother was “sometimes violent" and she was raised in her hometown of Woody Creek, Colorado, largely by "either her sisters or, being the youngest, left to her own devices.”

William H. Macy wrote a letter in defense of wife Felicity Huffman ahead of her sentencing in the college bribery scandal. But not everyone is buying what he says. More

It spurred her to create a different norm in her own home. From the time she discovered she was pregnant, “Felicity threw herself into parenting,” Macy wrote. “She read mountains of books and sought out the best and the brightest on the subject. She sought out parents whose children impressed her and picked their brains on child-rearing.”

It was Huffman, he says, who realized their then-6-year-old daughter, who had learning disabilities, would benefit from occupational therapy. "She was the first to notice Sophia's difficulty in school and was inexhaustible in getting an accurate diagnosis in treatment."

"But motherhood has, from the very beginning, frightened Felicity and she has not carried being a mom easily," Macy continued. "She’s struggled to find the balance between what the experts say and her common sense.”

Their daughter Sophia, he added, “paid the dearest price” in the scandal, after the college the aspiring actress hoped to attend, which “ironically, doesn’t require SAT scores” withdrew its invitation to audition.

"From the devastation of that day, Sophia is slowly regaining her equilibrium and getting on with her life. She still doesn’t like to sleep alone and has nightmares from the FBI agents waking her that morning with guns drawn.”

But on "The View" Monday, the women took issue with Macy's defense of Huffman – particularly her maternal anxieties.

“Welcome to the club, OK?” Joy Behar said. “Who wrote that speech? It's, like, out of 'Desperate Housewives.' ”

“Struggling to be a mom doesn't mean you break the law," added Meghan McCain. "Like, I had a hard time even understanding what the hell William H. Macy was even talking about."

McCain, who recently suffered a miscarriage, said she too has "a lot of fears about possibly becoming a mother." But the host said she doesn't "think that makes you bribe someone to break the law."

"They are the poster children for what everyone hates about white privilege, and she deserves to go to jail," said McCain. "I'm sorry, for a long period of time. For over a month."

On Friday, prosecutors recommended Huffman serve a month in prison for admitting to paying $15,000 to have her oldest daughter's SAT answers correctede.

Huffman's attorneys, however, asked a judge to sentence the actress to probation and "significant community service."

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Felicity Huffman: 'The View' slams William H. Macy's defense of wife
description: Felicity Huffman's relationship with her daughters has "exploded" and they are in therapy, husband William H. Macy writes ahead of her sentencing.
